name: PALESTINE CHILDRENS RELIEF FUND
mission: We provide free medical care and humanitarian aid for any child in the Middle East, regardless of their religion or politics.
programs:
CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT AND SUSTAINABILITY:
COMMUNITY-CENTERED AND INFRASTRUCTURE ENHANCEMENT
theoryOfChange: PCRF describes providing direct medical care and humanitarian aid to children lacking access to care, deploying international medical teams, sending children abroad for treatment, and rebuilding/establishing pediatric healthcare departments and facilities to bolster the region’s healthcare system.

evaluationSources: Charity Navigator 4-star rating for 12 consecutive years

zakatClaimEvidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://www.pcrf.net/donate (Source: https://www.pcrf.net/donate)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Good donor alignment with manageable risk. Evidence quality is solid but still evolving in places.

components.evidence: Explicit zakat program (+4); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Asnaf: masakin (+5); Operates in Muslim-majority regions (+3); Strong humanitarian service (+4)
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

components.improvement_suggestion: Expand services to underserved populations or geographies with limited nonprofit coverage.
components.name: Underserved Space

alignment.rationale: Alignment 40/50: HIGH Muslim donor fit, global health cause area

components.improvement_suggestion: Publish a time-bound plan to deploy excess unrestricted reserves into mission delivery, while keeping a clear operating reserve floor.
components.name: Financial Health

score_details.score_summary: PALESTINE CHILDRENS RELIEF FUND shows strong alignment and good impact, with zakat compliance.

zakat.claim_evidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://www.pcrf.net/donate (Source: https://www.pcrf.net/donate)

all_citations.claim: The organization reported a total revenue of $92,196,846 and a program expense ratio of 88.1%.
Financial data confirms a fundraising efficiency of $0.02 per $1 raised and 40.9 months of working capital.
PCRF provides free medical care and humanitarian aid regardless of religion or politics.
Programs include the distribution of flour, clean water, and the completion of medical missions.
The organization provides food vouchers and one-time surgical sponsorships for children.
Impact metrics include medical mission treatments and sponsorships for disabled youth.
The organization offers various giving methods for humanitarian relief.
The organization is Zakat-eligible and maintains a Zakat policy for donors.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization demonstrates strong financial health and high program spending, though its overall score reflects the complex costs associated with direct surgical and medical interventions in conflict zones.
areas_for_improvement: High cost per beneficiary relative to some global health interventions
Heavy reliance on volunteer medical missions which can be impacted by regional stability

dimension_explanations.alignment: The organization shows high alignment with donor interests in global health and humanitarian aid, particularly for those seeking Zakat-eligible opportunities [10]. Its long track record of providing non-political, non-religious aid in high-urgency zones establishes it as a primary responder in the region [3][8].
dimension_explanations.impact: PCRF achieves direct impact through medical mission treatments, surgical sponsorships, and the distribution of essential supplies like clean water and food [5][6]. While the cost per beneficiary is calculated at 7095.00512295082, this reflects the high-intensity nature of specialized pediatric medical care and infrastructure projects [2][7].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Palestine Children's Relief Fund provides life-saving medical care and humanitarian relief to children across the Middle East regardless of religion or politics.
strengths: High financial efficiency with a fundraising efficiency of $0.02 per $1 raised
Strong liquidity with 40.9 months of working capital available
Zakat-eligible status for Muslim donors seeking to fulfill religious obligations
baseline_narrative.summary: Founded to address the medical needs of children in the Middle East, the Palestine Children's Relief Fund (PCRF) operates through medical missions, infrastructure enhancement, and urgent response projects [3][5]. The organization reported a total revenue of $92,196,846 and maintains a high program expense ratio of 88.1% [1][2].

strengths.detail: The organization spends only <cite id="1">$0.02 per $1 raised</cite>, ensuring that the vast majority of donor contributions directly support programs.
PCRF directs <cite id="2">88.1% of its expenses</cite> to program services, maximizing the impact of its funding.
The charity is <cite id="10">zakat-eligible</cite>, allowing Muslim donors to fulfill their religious obligations while supporting critical medical care.

strengths_deep_dive: PCRF demonstrates strong financial health and operational efficiency. The organization reported <cite id="2">$92,196,846 in total revenue</cite> for 2023, with a remarkable <cite id="2">88.1% program expense ratio</cite>. This efficiency is further highlighted by its fundraising costs, which are just <cite id="1">$0.02 per $1 raised</cite>. The charity's impact is evident in its direct service delivery model, which includes <cite id="5">medical missions</cite> and <cite id="6">food vouchers</cite> for vulnerable populations in the Middle East.
rich_narrative.summary: The Palestine Children's Relief Fund (PCRF) provides life-saving medical care and humanitarian relief to children across the Middle East. Founded in <cite id="3">1991</cite>, the organization operates through medical missions, infrastructure enhancement, and urgent response projects. In 2023, PCRF reported <cite id="2">$92,196,846 in total revenue</cite> and directed <cite id="2">100.0% to program expenses</cite>. The charity demonstrates exceptional fundraising efficiency, spending just <cite id="1">$0.02 per $1 raised</cite>. PCRF's programs reach vulnerable populations in the <cite id="3">Gaza Strip, Egypt, West Bank, Lebanon, and Jordan</cite>, providing critical interventions such as <cite id="6">medical mission treatments</cite> and <cite id="5">clean water delivery</cite>. The organization is <cite id="10">zakat-eligible</cite>, making it a strong option for Muslim donors seeking to fulfill their religious obligations while supporting urgent humanitarian needs in the region.
